item.title: Mortal Engines review – Peter Jackson's steampunk Star Wars stalls - The Guardian
item.description:
Mortal Engines review – Peter Jackson's steampunk Star Wars stalls  The Guardian

Mortal Engines was originally a YA dystopian adventure novel from British author Philip Reeve, published in 2001, the first of the “Mortal Engines quartet”. Among its many fans is Peter Jackson, who has now turned it into a tiringly frenetic and derivative fantasy-adventure movie, co-producing and co-writing the adaptation with Fran Walsh and Philippa Boyens. Making his directing debut here is Jackson’s former storyboard artist and visual effects supervisor Christian Rivers. The film is basically a steampunk Star Wars, with a bit of low-octane Gilliam and Gaiman on the side. By the end, in ...

item.title: Mortal Engines review: A better adaptation than The Golden Compass but overstuffed with detail - The Independent
item.description:
Mortal Engines review: A better adaptation than The Golden Compass but overstuffed with detail  The Independent

Dir; Christian Rivers; Starring: Hugo Weaving, Hera Hilmar, Robert Sheehan, Jihae, Stephen Lang. Cert 12A, 128 mins Mortal Engines, an adaptation of the first of a quartet of fantasy books by Philip Reeve, has been heavily framed in its publicity as the latest brainchild of filmmaking wizard Peter Jackson. It’s a small twist of the truth: it’s actually the directorial debut of his protégé Christian Rivers, who has worked closely with Jackson since 1992’s Braindead. Rivers, however, has learnt much from his master and, arguably, Mortal Engines could be described as coming from the “school of...

item.title: Mortal Engines review: a mechanical, soulless dystopian theme park ride to nowhere - The Telegraph
item.description:
Mortal Engines review: a mechanical, soulless dystopian theme park ride to nowhere  The Telegraph

Dir: Christian Rivers. Cast: Hera Hilmar, Robert Sheehan, Hugo Weaving, JiHAE, Stephen Lang, Patrick Malahide, Leila George, Frankie Adams. 12A cert, 128 mins Mortal Engines, a Young Adult steampunk epic from the Lord of the Rings stable, puts London on wheels, advancing voraciously across Europe in a curious inverse-of-Brexit nightmare after global apocalypse has struck. This motorised metropolis, with St Paul’s poking out the top of it and various landmarks jammed into its flanks, rolls clanking and heaving across the continent with a giant maw agape in its front, designed to hoover up ot...

item.title: UK film release dates: What new movies are coming to British cinemas? - The Independent
item.description:
UK film release dates: What new movies are coming to British cinemas?  The Independent

The year may be drawing to a close but there's no shortage of exciting new titles coming to UK cinemas. January and February always see a deluge of new prestige pictures released in time for awards season as we build up towards the Oscars. Here’s an overview of all the new releases hitting British screens over the coming months. Out now Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald A sequel to Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016), JK Rowling’s prequel series to Harry Potter, this new instalment is again directed by franchise regular David Yates and once more stars Eddie Redmayne as ...

item.title: Predator Cities Fight for Survival in Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines' - VOA News
item.description:
Predator Cities Fight for Survival in Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines'  VOA News

Oscar-winning filmmaker Peter Jackson is returning to the big screen with adventure fantasy "Mortal Engines," a post-apocalyptic tale of survival in his first feature film project since his award-winning adaptations of J.R.R. Tolkien's novels. The New Zealand-born director, known for his "The Lord of the Rings" and "The Hobbit" trilogies, produced and co-wrote the script for the film, based on the young adult book series by Philip Reeve. Oscar-winning visual effects artist Christian Rivers, who worked with Jackson on the Tolkien adaptations as well as 2005's "King Kong" makes his directoria...

item.title: The Truth About Nic Cage, David Bowie And The Casting Of 'Lord Of The Rings' - HuffPost
item.description:
The Truth About Nic Cage, David Bowie And The Casting Of 'Lord Of The Rings'  HuffPost

It was the one viral “Lord of the Rings” rumor to rule them all. In an interview with Newsweek in 2015, Nic Cage talked about choosing to live life without regrets, and in the process, happily outlined one very specific thing that he definitely doesn’t regret: turning down the role of Aragorn in “Lord of the Rings.” “There were different things going on in my life at the time that precluded me from being able to travel and be away from home for three years,” he said. In response, the internet lit up brighter than the Shire when Gandalf breaks out the fireworks. Could Nic Cage have actually ...

item.title: Mortal Engines trailer: Peter Jackson and director Christian Rivers on what fans can expect from the book adaptation - The Independent
item.description:
Mortal Engines trailer: Peter Jackson and director Christian Rivers on what fans can expect from the book adaptation  The Independent

“London is on the move again.” It’s this curious line, branded across the back cover, that attracted many a young reader to Philip Reeve’s 2001 novel Mortal Engines. Within its pages, the vision of a post-apocalyptic world ravaged by a mysterious event known as the Sixty Minute War, in which many of the world’s cities have become mobilised; now transformed into great mechanical beasts on wheels, known as Traction Cities, roaming across the land in search of smaller cities to devour for their resources. Within this world unfolds a story of revolution, justice, and revenge: as a young man, To...

item.title: Trailer: Can Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines' Restart The YA Fantasy Franchise? - Forbes Now
item.description:
Trailer: Can Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines' Restart The YA Fantasy Franchise?  Forbes Now

Robert Sheehan, Hera Hilmar, and Leifur Sigurdarson in ‘Mortal Engines’ (2018) The trailers keep coming. Universal/Comcast Corp. just dropped a second theatrical trailer for the Peter Jackson-produced and Christian Rivers-directed Mortal Engines. Yes, this is another shot at making a new YA fantasy franchise series along with Jennifer Nelson Yuh’s The Darkest Minds in August, but the films flourished as female-centric counterparts to the usually male-centric superhero flicks. That’s not to say that this next batch will be anywhere near as successful as Twilight, Harry Potter or Hunger Games...

item.title: Future shock: unearthing the most cutting-edge sci-fi movies of 2018 - The Guardian
item.description:
Future shock: unearthing the most cutting-edge sci-fi movies of 2018  The Guardian

If the 2017 box office was typified by any one movie, it was surely Rian Johnson’s Star Wars: The Last Jedi, a smart, intelligently curated yet ever so slightly soulless example of machine-honed franchise film-making. It ticked every box for fans of the venerable space saga, without ever really pushing the envelope; a movie that eventually made the Kessel Run, but 40 years or so after Han Solo and Chewie had already achieved that legendary feat. Related: The most exciting sci-fi, fantasy and horror films of 2018 The Last Jedi, like Spider-Man: Homecoming, Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 an...

item.title: Trailer: Can Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines' Succeed Where 'Warcraft' Failed? - Forbes Now
item.description:
Trailer: Can Peter Jackson's 'Mortal Engines' Succeed Where 'Warcraft' Failed?  Forbes Now

‘Mortal Engines’ Now that’s a teaser… I actually “snuck” into a 6:00 pm showing of The Last Jedi on Thursday night (with permission from the theater employees) between a showing of Call Me By Your Name and my 7:30 pm press screening of The Greatest Showman in order to watch the trailers attached to said Star Wars sequel, partially in the hopes that I would catch a glimpse of this “only in theaters” teaser for Mortal Engines. Alas, that the teaser was one of a few biggies (also Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom) that didn’t play with the Walt Disney blockbuster, although both Black Panther and ...

item.title: Mortal Engines trailer: The first footage from Peter Jackson's fantasy movie has finally landed - The Independent
item.description:
Mortal Engines trailer: The first footage from Peter Jackson's fantasy movie has finally landed  The Independent

Ever since the third instalment of The Hobbit debuted in 2014, Peter Jackson has been remarkably absent from cinemas. Next Christmas, though, he will finally return with Mortal Engines. Jackson has written and produced the adaptation of Phillip Reeve’s novel, with Christian Rivers — who acted as visual effects supervisor on Lord of the Rings, splinter unit director on The Hobbit, and has storyboarded every Jackson film since Braindead — directing. The first trailer for the fantasy adventure has been released, showing the great mobile cities that characterised the novel. Peter Jackson presen...
